commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: If8e5839dee564f975804a2a661180e47c5107caf

[{'created': '2021-03-17 14:47:30.000000000', 'message': 'Drop dep on python-masakariclient

There is no logic in python-masakariclient that masakari-dashboard
requires. It is safe to drop. The check for supported API versions
was irrelevant already as it depends directly on OpenStack SDK.

Change-Id: I97c6db49f1a4dbd36f7003299938a05994e37cb6
'}]
commit_message:
Drop dep on python-masakariclient

There is no logic in python-masakariclient that masakari-dashboard
requires. It is safe to drop. The check for supported API versions
was irrelevant already as it depends directly on OpenStack SDK.

Change-Id: I97c6db49f1a4dbd36f7003299938a05994e37cb6

I wonder if it will not be better to use settings in the config-map, like the way it's done for tags."}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2021-02-24 15:25:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I wonder if it will not be better to use settings in the config-map, like the way it's done for tags.

Note that we need to allow the user setting an annotation to the Kubernetes Service with a different value than the default supported values. The user is not supposed to change anything on KuryrLoadbalancer Custom Resource directly (only kuryr should update it), but instead change the Service with one annotation (we should define it) and Kuryr will react to that."}, {'account_id': 32533, 'date': '2021-02-24 15:29:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> Note that we need to allow the user setting an annotation to the Kubernetes Service with a different value than the default supported values. The user is not supposed to change anything on KuryrLoadbalancer Custom Resource directly (only kuryr should update it), but instead change the Service with one annotation (we should define it) and Kuryr will react to that.

Oh okay, thank you."}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2021-02-24 15:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

thanks, Tabitha. Few more thoughts:'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2021-02-25 08:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the update. It’s still needed to also retrieve the timeouts value from a possible annotation that the user adds to the Service. Note that the user may not be allowed to modify the config-map that is why we need to add support to reading from annotation. We can also include in the docs what is the name of annotation.'}, {'account_id': 32533, 'date': '2021-02-26 14:46:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Note that the user may not be allowed to modify the config-map that is why we need to add support to reading from annotation. We can also include in the docs what is the name of annotation.

By annotating the service, do you mean for example adding timeout fields to the service manifest?'}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2021-02-26 15:07:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > Thanks for the update. It’s still needed to also retrieve the timeouts value from a possible annotation that the user adds to the Service. Note that the user may not be allowed to modify the config-map that is why we need to add support to reading from annotation. We can also include in the docs what is the name of annotation.
> 
> By annotating the service, do you mean for example adding timeout fields to the service manifest?

yes, we need to handle the timeout annotation on the Service's metadata[1] that the user could add. The kuryrLoadBalancer CRD could then be filled with either the default value or the value set by the User on the annotation. Note that Kuryr already reads annotations from the Pods on the PodLabelHandler for example.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/annotations/"}, {'account_id': 32533, 'date': '2021-02-26 15:25:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

[1] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/master/octavia/db/prepare.py#L123"}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2021-03-15 09:29:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Do we need to know the default value being used on octavia side? Probably we just need to know if we set or not annotation on the service, and if those are on the status side. Then, to apply the default one probably it is enough to call the listener creation without the timeout and that should apply whatever default if configured at the moment on Octavia side."}, {'account_id': 32533, 'date': '2021-03-15 12:08:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

We don't need to know the default value for most of the use cases except this one Maysa mentioned. I'm still looking for a way around this."}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2021-03-15 18:07:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> 
> We don't need to know the default value for most of the use cases except this one Maysa mentioned. I'm still looking for a way around this.

I guess we can take into consideration the annotations when their value is different than 0 and just check if it is different than the listener created and if it's enforce the new value. This way we don't need to rely on the octavia defaults. It would be good to include this on the docs.
wdyt?"}, {'account_id': 32533, 'date': '2021-03-15 18:21:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

[{'created': '2021-02-24 14:59:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add option to set listener timeouts for lb created by Kuryr

The timeout-client-data and timeout-member-data configurations for Octavia
listeners default to 50 seconds for load balancers created by Kuryr. This patch
allows the creation and modification of load balancers handled by Kuryr with
different timeouts values.

Implements: blueprint configure-lb-listeners-timeout
Change-Id: I99016001c2263023d1fa2637d7b5aeb23b3b2d9d

commit_message:
Add option to set listener timeouts for lb created by Kuryr

The timeout-client-data and timeout-member-data configurations
for Octavia listeners default to 50 seconds for load balancers
created by Kuryr. This patch allows the creation and modification
of load balancers handled by Kuryr with different timeouts values.

Implements: blueprint configure-lb-listeners-timeout
Change-Id: I99016001c2263023d1fa2637d7b5aeb23b3b2d9d

commit_message:
Do not permit IPA standalone to be enabled by conf

IPA standalone mode is a developer-only option, and if enabled
accidentally on a production agent could cause undesired behavior.

Developers who need this behavior should build a purpose-built agent,
with standalone hardcoded to True in cmd/agent.py.

Change-Id: Icc67dbe15acbbf6fee886f274d2169a0769a5053

commit_message:
Add missing boilerplate

.gitreview, .zuul.yaml, .jujuignore, copyright
Also align tox.ini with charm-ceph-iscsi.

Also temporarily disable Zaza tests as we don't have
the necessary NetApp ONTAP cluster deployed yet in
order to run them.

Change-Id: Ic12afbccfe8a3bf15e1dbb42ed093164d9aeaed6

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-25 15:20:42.000000000', 'message': 'Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I3abd87790e34e4549917705ae1c2f5e92363575a
'}]
commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-25 15:20:35.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7a9cfbd32bd720befb4f26a75e82100b6921afaf
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7a9cfbd32bd720befb4f26a75e82100b6921afaf

Third-party CI has passed, so upgrading my vote.'}, {'account_id': 31721, 'date': '2021-03-24 13:52:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> Code looks good.  Comment about the tests inline.  Only a +1 because the third party CI hasn't passed yet on patch set 2.

Thank you Brian for the review. Currently, the is_flexgroup and _clone_file_supported cannot be both true, in the future it will. Then, we can address this scenario later on the unit tests. The CI passed now, thanks for retriggering it!"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-03-24 14:16:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)

A couple minor nits, but those can be addressed later. No point in holding this up for now.'}]

commit_message:
Follow up NetApp ONTAP FlexGroup feature

It is a follow up to the patch [1], providing the fixes:

1. Check the ONTAP storage version for the FlexGroup feature.
The feature is only accepted whether the ONTAP is 9.8 or greater.

2. Remove multiattach support for flexgroup pools.

3. Start bumping the driver version with its documentation.

4. Update the flexgroup release notes.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/776713

Change-Id: I0636b6530a79f8ca86db52f87273ec822c3cb406

commit_message:
Bump max Ansible version to 2.10

Molecule also needs to be bumped to support Ansible 2.10
lint: section changed in Molecule 3.x - adapted.
molecule-docker added do test-reqs because it code has moved to it from
molecule core
pytest-testinfra and pytest-molecule needed for testinfra tests to work

[1]: https://github.com/ansible-community/molecule/issues/2872

Change-Id: I0299f5126ebd080f3912a76294b0013abe7747a0

commit_message:
Drop lower-constraints

Per our PTG resolution [1] and general OpenStack resolution [2], lower-constraints
are not worth the extra work and confusion they introduce.
This patch drops them along with all mentions.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-October/018445.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019521.html

Change-Id: I58807c27fd20c7269019e26e8b507744d35325f3
(cherry picked from commit 8e9323d236a26a6514cdc5a60ac220a50a81abc7)

commit_message:
Debian: install newer firmware for qemu/aarch64

Nova looks into /usr/share/qemu/firmware/ directory. We need 2020.05
version of firmware package for it.

ERROR: nova.exception.InternalError: Failed to locate firmware descriptor files
Change-Id: I546bcf910e886eb75ece62f6be382fe1187efb32

commit_message:
Add Ghanshyam nomination as chair

I would like to nominate myself as chair of the
Technical Committee for Xena cycle.

I am serving as TC since Stein cycle, which is 3rd year. I am
trying my best to be more active in TC and leading the things
in various form, for example, community-wide goal, TC discussion
or any reach out to project teams. As TC chair, I would like to
continue the same and try to improve the TC interaction with
rest of the community.

Having my majority of the job time for upstream activities will help
me to fulfil all the TC chair duties[1] and to drive the new initiative
from TC or community.

Thanks for considering my nomination.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/CHAIR.rst

Change-Id: I856b360111339e25c50fbaed6b00a6c58472dc92

commit_message:
Remove extra/vif_port_id

Removes API translation layer into port/portgroup internal_info
Removes internal logic to support use of VIFs stored in the extra
field, which effectively means all vif binding must now utilize
vif attachment and detachment.

This is a change that we likely should have pushed forward a couple
years back, but I didn't want to break compatability with very old
of ironic or standalone users which were deploying instances using
very old instructions. That being said, it is necessary to remove
the legacy vif support so new access controls can properly wrap
vif API endpoints.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin/+/769204
Change-Id: I588b3a64475656542389ff83786189e2dc16d35c

[{'created': '2021-03-24 05:38:06.000000000', 'message': "Add config parameter 'live_migration_scheme' to live migration with tls guide

This patch adds the config option 'live_migration_scheme = tls' to the
secure live migration guide.

To let the live migration use the qemu native tls, some configuration of
the compute nodes is needed. The guide describes this but misses the
'live_migration_scheme' config option.

It is necessary to set 'live_migration_scheme' to tls to use the
connection uri for encrypted traffic. Without this parameter everything
seems to work, but the unencrypted tcp-connection is still used for the
live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1919357
Change-Id: Ia5130d411706bf7e1c983156158011a3bc6d5cd6
(cherry picked from commit 5d5ff82bab1dfb12e6223446b1cf20db6a348f38)

"}]
commit_message:
Add config parameter 'live_migration_scheme' to live migration with tls guide

This patch adds the config option 'live_migration_scheme = tls' to the
secure live migration guide.

To let the live migration use the qemu native tls, some configuration of
the compute nodes is needed. The guide describes this but misses the
'live_migration_scheme' config option.

It is necessary to set 'live_migration_scheme' to tls to use the
connection uri for encrypted traffic. Without this parameter everything
seems to work, but the unencrypted tcp-connection is still used for the
live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1919357
Change-Id: Ia5130d411706bf7e1c983156158011a3bc6d5cd6
(cherry picked from commit 5d5ff82bab1dfb12e6223446b1cf20db6a348f38)
(cherry picked from commit 276b8db5afd945bfc56ccfadd25bcce1b6df9cb7)
(cherry picked from commit a968289b1f89b52d7396b66294f768c732583849)

commit_message:
Proposing Wallaby RC1 for blazar

If you wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the release,
someone from your team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that patch
with a different commit SHA.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday March 26.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 6.0.0..d3f77fd
d3f77fd Add usage enforcement framework
77cf902 Change dashes to underscore in setup.cfg
d14668b Drop unused sqlalchemy-migrate requirement
3f1c1ed [goal] Deprecate the JSON formatted policy file
7d131c9 Re-use rpc transport
37bee67 Make lower-constraints job non-voting
b1841dc Fix use of legacy Alembic API
e81bbc7 remove unicode from code
ae43ea3 Remove six
963097e Add doc/requirements
4f642c8 Fix lower-constraints job
a1ecf0d Remove misplaced return statement
ccf1727 Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE
0847f7e Remove unused DB utility functions
368403e Remove the unused coding style modules
4935706 bump py37 to py38 in tox.ini
184dbcc Reuse the docs deps to benefit from constraints
38189e1 Remove Babel requirement
021d1d7 Add Python3 wallaby unit tests
d8ddf42 Update master for stable/victoria

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id9fa9981a50a74ceb5fa818a71f9790f4a1c7097

commit_message:
Disable libvirtd.service before starting sockets

This change makes sure that libvirtd.service is stopped when starting
libvirtd-tcp/tls.socket, because these socket fails to start if
libvirtd.service is already running.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/759595/
Change-Id: I4a670aa77f0f0406a96db07877354b5067ddf1da
(cherry picked from commit 451f5203214ede6738cce5f2abeeae93a7f8ae36)
(cherry picked from commit 675474d0e55e1c7504ecfdcba65723aea4656142)
(cherry picked from commit 736a330cd2084fae4ac3199e5cf6b693f6fedd3a)

Core reviewers for neutron-lib stable branches were in
neutron-lib-stable-maint group. But this group i now empty and based on
current state of neutron and neutron-lib projects, I think that we can
replace that neutron-lib-stable-maint group with neutron-stable-maint
group so neutron stable cores will have same permissions in the
neutron-lib's stable branches as well.

Change-Id: Ied0b9820cdf86505380f2392a53ffeb130d0421f
"}]
commit_message:
Add neutron stable cores +2 powers in stable neutron-lib branches

Core reviewers for neutron-lib stable branches were in
neutron-lib-stable-maint group. But this group i now empty and based on
current state of neutron and neutron-lib projects, I think that we can
replace that neutron-lib-stable-maint group with neutron-stable-maint
group so neutron stable cores will have same permissions in the
neutron-lib's stable branches as well.

Change-Id: Ied0b9820cdf86505380f2392a53ffeb130d0421f

commit_message:
Add log for cron script fernet-rotate.sh

This change also changes the out-format of rsync to put a timestamp,
file name, last-modified time of the file and bytes transferred

Change-Id: I98305858c4fcb428997d5f85780fe644e07fbed3

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 935, 'name': 'James Page', 'email': 'james.page@canonical.com', 'username': 'james-page'}, {'_account_id': 20634, 'name': 'Chris MacNaughton', 'email': 'chris.macnaughton@canonical.com', 'username': 'Chris.MacNaughton'}, {'_account_id': 20648, 'name': 'Canonical CI', 'email': 'uosci-testing-bot@ubuntu.com', 'username': 'uosci-testing-bot', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 20870, 'name': 'Alex Kavanagh', 'email': 'alex.kavanagh@canonical.com', 'username': 'ajkavanagh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24890, 'name': 'Alvaro Uría', 'email': 'alvaro.uria@canonical.com', 'username': 'aluria'}, {'_account_id': 30561, 'name': 'Peter Matulis', 'email': 'peter.matulis@canonical.com', 'username': 'pmatulis'}]

(13 comments)

Overall, change looks good. I've added some comments inline and I will run manual tests to verify each action + rollback procedure."}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-11-25 10:19:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24890, 'date': '2020-11-25 10:53:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24890, 'date': '2020-11-25 13:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

While manually testing the actions, I hit:
 $ juju run-action --wait nova-compute/1 disable
unit-nova-compute-1:
  UnitId: nova-compute/1
  id: "8"
  message: exit status 1
  results:
    ReturnCode: 1
    Stderr: |
      Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "/var/lib/juju/agents/unit-nova-compute-1/charm/actions/disable", line 25, in <module>
          from nova_compute import cloud_utils
        File "lib/nova_compute/cloud_utils.py", line 18, in <module>
          from keystoneauth1 import loading, session
      ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'keystoneauth1'
  status: failed
  timing:
    completed: 2020-11-25 13:49:03 +0000 UTC
    enqueued: 2020-11-25 13:48:54 +0000 UTC
    started: 2020-11-25 13:48:55 +0000 UTC

It seems the install (and upgrade-charm) hook may also need to install this apt package (or verify that it is installed).'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-11-25 16:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-11-25 16:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(12 comments)'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-11-27 17:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 24890, 'date': '2020-11-30 16:40:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 24890, 'date': '2020-12-01 10:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

When running the "disable" action, only the Nova services are disabled. Not the OVS/OVN agents. A compute node may run more agents than the neutron-openvswitch-agent one. For instance, a DHCP agent can be managed by each compute node, and by not disabling that agent, DHCP services for tenant networks may land on the theoretically disabled compute node.

Since "remove-from-cloud" and "register-to-cloud" deal with Neutron agents, I think "disable" and "enable" actions should also deal with them.

OTOH, "remove-from-cloud" stops services, but does not mask them. A node reboot (or neutron-ovs-agent restart) would re-register the agent(s). If a single service is rebooted, nova-compute service will be unregistered but neutron-openvswitch-agent will be. Another run of "remove-from-cloud" would fail but it can be worked around by running "register-to-cloud" and re-running "remove-from-cloud". Nevertheless, what would you think about masking stopped services so they can't re-register until such action is run?

Other than the above, manual testing and code looks good.

As discussed, func tests are pending. Thank you for the change!'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-12-01 14:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> When running the "disable" action, only the Nova services are disabled. Not the OVS/OVN agents. A compute node may run more agents than the neutron-openvswitch-agent one. For instance, a DHCP agent can be managed by each compute node, and by not disabling that agent, DHCP services for tenant networks may land on the theoretically disabled compute node.
> 
> Since "remove-from-cloud" and "register-to-cloud" deal with Neutron agents, I think "disable" and "enable" actions should also deal with them.
> 
> OTOH, "remove-from-cloud" stops services, but does not mask them. A node reboot (or neutron-ovs-agent restart) would re-register the agent(s). If a single service is rebooted, nova-compute service will be unregistered but neutron-openvswitch-agent will be. Another run of "remove-from-cloud" would fail but it can be worked around by running "register-to-cloud" and re-running "remove-from-cloud". Nevertheless, what would you think about masking stopped services so they can't re-register until such action is run?
> 
> Other than the above, manual testing and code looks good.
> 
> As discussed, func tests are pending. Thank you for the change!

As we discussed in the chat, if disabling of the neutron agent is needed, it should be implemented as part of the neutron agent charm, it shouldn't be a side effect of the nova-compute disable.

I agree with the service masking though, I'll get right on it.'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2020-12-01 15:11:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 24890, 'date': '2020-12-02 16:38:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

The new functional tests in the linked PR only include tests for the enable and disable actions. I want to see functional tests added to cover the whole flow (disable -> evacuate instances (not via this change) -> remove-from-cloud -> register-to-cloud -> enable, rather than just disable -> enable.'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2021-01-15 15:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2021-01-15 15:44:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I added functional test requested by Chriss. Workflow is bit different from suggested, because in CI environment there's no need to disable nova-compute before running `remove-from-cloud` action. Chaining all 4 actions would create more complicated testcase. Instead there are two tests, one runs `enable`/`disable` actions, second runs `remove-from-cloud`/`register-to-cloud`.

Minor note: Since the Test class that contains these tests now covers all the actions from `actions/cloud.py` I renamed the class to `CloudActions`."}, {'account_id': 32288, 'date': '2021-01-16 16:34:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

commit_message:
Added actions that enable clean removal of nova-compute unit from model

List of added actions:
* disable
* enable
* remove-from-cloud
* register-to-cloud

More detailed explanation of the process added to the README.md

Closes-Bug: #1691998
Change-Id: I45d1def2ca0b1289f6fcce06c5f8949ef2a4a69e
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/470

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-01 07:37:45.000000000', 'message': 'Refactoring - add pool of ports to be used in tests

All tests are running in parallel on the same LB created by setup.
As the result we had to manage ports used to create listeners
in manuall manner, in order to avoid conflicts, by increasing
port number on each new test.
This patch adds pool of ports as a class attribute and each test
pulls the unique port using Python's "pop" from list function.

Change-Id: Ib11ea79710615e671908d31daa6785ad6e13b8e9

'}, {'created': '2021-01-28 08:50:45.000000000', 'message': 'Refactoring - add pool of ports to be used in tests

In order to prevent "port conflicts" while parallel execution of the tests,
we had to increase the port number while adding new tests, by increasing the
last used port (+1).
This patch adds "pool of ports" as a class attribute.
Each test must pull the unique port number from that pool of ports,
for example:
test_port = self.pool_of_ports['http_range'].pop(0)
will pull the unique HTTP port.

commit_message:
Refactoring - add pool of ports to be used in tests

In order to prevent "port conflicts" while parallel execution of the tests,
we had to increase the port number while adding new tests, by increasing the
last used port (+1).
This patch adds "pool of ports" as a class attribute.
Each test must pull the unique port number from that pool of ports,
for example:
test_port = self.pool_of_ports['http_range'].pop(0)
will pull the unique HTTP port.

Change-Id: Ib11ea79710615e671908d31daa6785ad6e13b8e9

[{'created': '2021-03-19 12:47:25.000000000', 'message': 'Proposing Wallaby RC1 for kuryr-kubernetes

If you wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the release,
someone from your team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that patch
with a different commit SHA.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday March 26.

ef621960 optimize size and time using --no-cache-dir

44890a84 Set read timeout for any request in K8sClient
9794359e requirements: Drop os-testr
cd5a2ee8 Skip update of vip sg if lb is gone
df53e145 Ensure klb handler reacretes lb
68dd879d Bump py37 to py38 in tox.ini
5b2c399d Clean up unused methods and not needed interactions to k8s API.
ab374e5d Don't crash on fetching network policy.
4e16d440 Add Python3 wallaby unit tests
1f8da63a Update master for stable/victoria
87090288 Avoid race when pod is deleted before finalizer is added
bee7718a Cleanup ports belonging to deleted nodes

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie7a99d80d2b47c0da0ffbaa2cb161a7b5480bcc8

Proposing Wallaby RC1 for kuryr-kubernetes

someone from your team can -1 the patch to have it held, or update that patch
with a different commit SHA.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday March 26.

commit_message:
Make baremetal --debug actually work

The --debug option exists but does nothing. Wire in openstacksdk logging
and make sure ironicclient can log as well.

Change-Id: I136503f546be2ecbd3203ee07597df59a40a594e
(cherry picked from commit 4a22f29f1e439d20b66a5f20de1d501b11a4d385)

commit_message:
Make baremetal --debug actually work

The --debug option exists but does nothing. Wire in openstacksdk logging
and make sure ironicclient can log as well.

Change-Id: I136503f546be2ecbd3203ee07597df59a40a594e
(cherry picked from commit 4a22f29f1e439d20b66a5f20de1d501b11a4d385)

commit_message:
Add a configurable URL base to staticweb

This came to light because someone ran Tempest against a standard
installation of RDO, which helpfuly terminates SSL for Swift in
a pre-configured load-balancer. In such a case, staticweb has no
way to know what scheme to use and guesses wrong, causing Tempest
to fail.

Related upstream bug:
 https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/+bug/1537071

Change-Id: Ie15cf2aff4f7e6bcf68b67ae733c77bb9353587a
Closes-Bug: 1572011

commit_message:
Include missing Ironic puppet base step config

Ironic base puppet step config is ignored by API and conductor
services. Include it to apply the missed puppet configurations
for the base class.

Change-Id: I669c225b62ca40da579dcaf1c5213be2a3ed5923
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Change new policy rules for availability zones API

It was previously set that both SYSTEM and PROJECT READER could get
access to it. But this resource don't have project_id so PROJECT_READER
should be removed from that rule and only SYSTEM scope users should be
able to get it.

This patch also adds UT for policies for that API.

Related-blueprint: bp/secure-rbac-roles
Change-Id: Idfaf36c3dd003c9c5c1ce3f9ee889ba54643e831

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.
However, in 'monasca_agent/collector/virt/libvirt/inspector.py' file these options cannot be
provided by a configuration file. Changing this to retrieve both options from
'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' file.

Change-Id: I1918fda471e951f42db0d302e371108b664e936c
(cherry picked from commit 085f64578f40152273138898a0dc4566d327dc8f)
"}]
commit_message:
Set 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options in the 'libvirt' plugin to be defined in conf.d/libvirt.yaml

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.
However, in 'monasca_agent/collector/virt/libvirt/inspector.py' file these options cannot be
provided by a configuration file. Changing this to retrieve both options from
'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' file.

Change-Id: I1918fda471e951f42db0d302e371108b664e936c
(cherry picked from commit 085f64578f40152273138898a0dc4566d327dc8f)

commit_message:
Optimize bluestore deployment in kolla-ansible

Adjust the naming of osd related disk variables and optimize the
deployment of bluestore.

Update bluestore usage documentation.

Depends-On: Ic2cd282eb81368b7361a8012544e0b240102e3f5

Change-Id: I602f1b48f8390a04e340368280ece6e6d1317474
Closes-bug: #1776888

commit_message:
docs: Remove duplicated PCI passthrough extra spec info

There's also a PCI passthrough guide. Use that instead, allowing us to
remove the sections for various extra specs from the 'user/flavors'
guide:

- hw:pci_numa_affinity_policy
- pci_passthrough:alias

Change-Id: I5701d284c2cfdadf825f8e2f699651b3f8c0c9ab
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-13 03:29:56.000000000', 'message': 'Support one by one to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, one by one, please refer
to the documentation for details:
doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069
'}, {'created': '2018-07-13 05:17:06.000000000', 'message': 'Support one by one to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, one by one, it has the
following features:

1. Only upgrade one ceph component on one node at a time.
2. Perform ceph status detection before upgrading each component,
upgrade only in HEALTH_OK state.
3.When upgrading osd, noout and norebalance are set before the upgrade
to prevent data rebalancing. The osd upgrade on the same node is also
one by one.

please refer to the documentation for details:
doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069
'}, {'created': '2018-07-19 10:04:52.000000000', 'message': 'Support one by one to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, one by one, it has the
following features:

1. Only upgrade one ceph component on one node at a time.
2. Perform ceph status detection before upgrading each component,
upgrade only in HEALTH_OK state.
3.When upgrading osd, noout and norebalance are set before the upgrade
to prevent data rebalancing. The osd upgrade on the same node is also
one by one.

please refer to the documentation for details:
kolla-ansible/doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069
'}, {'created': '2018-07-24 08:27:13.000000000', 'message': 'Support serial mode to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, serial mode, it has the
following features:

1. Only upgrade one ceph component on one node at a time.
2. Perform ceph status detection before upgrading each component,
upgrade only in HEALTH_OK state.
3.When upgrading osd, noout and norebalance are set before the upgrade
to prevent data rebalancing. The osd upgrade on the same node is also
run in sequence.

Please refer to the "Deploy ceph individually and upgrade securely"
section in the kolla-ansible documentation[0].

[0] kolla-ansible/doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069
'}]
commit_message:
Support serial mode to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, serial mode, it has the
following features:

1. Only upgrade one ceph component on one node at a time.
2. Perform ceph status detection before upgrading each component,
upgrade only in HEALTH_OK state.
3.When upgrading osd, noout and norebalance are set before the upgrade
to prevent data rebalancing. The osd upgrade on the same node is also
run in sequence.

Please refer to the "Deploy ceph individually and upgrade securely"
section in the kolla-ansible documentation[0].

[0] kolla-ansible/doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069

commit_message:
docs: Add a real-time guide

This beefy patch closes a long-standing TODO and allows us to move yet
more information out of the flavors guide and into specific documents.
This, combined with existing documentation in place, means we can remove
the sections for various extra specs from the 'user/flavors' guide:

- hw:cpu_realtime            -> doc/source/admin/real-time.rst
- hw:cpu_realtime_mask       -> doc/source/admin/real-time.rst
- hw:emulator_threads_policy -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_policy              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_thread_policy       -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_sockets             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_cores               -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_threads             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_sockets         -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_cores           -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_threads         -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_nodes              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_cpus.N             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_mem.N              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:mem_page_size           -> doc/source/admin/huge-pages.rst

Multiple improvements to the libvirt extra spec docs are included here,
for want of a better place to include them.

Change-Id: I02b044f8246f4a42481bb5f00259842692b29b71
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[WIP] Use kolla-cli in gate jobs

This work is very much in debug and should be ignored for now.
The idea is that deploy, upgrade, etc will be done with the kolla-cli.
It will likely take many iterations to get this to work.

Depends-On: I4dc1e1ce8d1839e7550479799fb00e2613d979df

Change-Id: I6cd898460aa4bbe68d3f86bc7733d58ac74f392f

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

When deploying ceph_mon node, it will check cluster interface
and if there has no that interface,kolla-ansible will raise an
error, but this is not necessary for ceph itself.

commit_message:
Fix ceph_mon check ceph cluster network

When deploying ceph_mon node, it will check cluster interface
and if there has no that interface,kolla-ansible will raise an
error, but this is not necessary for ceph itself.

Reslove by generating different configure task depends on different
ceph roles.

Change-Id: I64e5b3ee9136235070661685e72e4c6fa411cda4
Closes-Bug: #1729589

Change-Id: I80198d773d9cf9fdae72cfc649b533e1d14bb181
'}, {'created': '2019-05-13 21:46:08.000000000', 'message': "Use testenv deps instead of repeating the dependencies

The list of dependencies was incomplete in several tox environments.
Instead of replicating it, simply refer to the master testenv dependency
list. We can also move linter dependencies into tox.ini directly as
they're blacklisted in global-requirements so cinder can pick the
version on its own, and they don't need to be tracked on
*requirements.txt. This has also the advantage that it doesn't get
unnecessarily pulled into other tox environments.

Also use white space indenting consistently to be easier on the
eyes.

commit_message:
Use testenv deps instead of repeating the dependencies

The list of dependencies was incomplete in several tox environments.
Instead of replicating it, simply refer to the master testenv dependency
list.

Also use white space indenting consistently to be easier on the
eyes.

Change-Id: I80198d773d9cf9fdae72cfc649b533e1d14bb181

commit_message:
Update virtual media boot-related constants

Constants related to virtual media boot are modified to identify LC and
RAC event messages only, and not the version.

Story: 2008708
Task: 42042

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: I151e1cae71e4fd69db8e995e7464f109041a3990

commit_message:
Update RETRY_COUNT for virtual media boot

Increase RETRY_COUNT to 35 to provide sufficient time to complete
already running iDRAC configuration job. This has been observed when
ironic performs boot mode synchronization, because the node boot mode
is not the same as bare-metal boot mode.

Story: 2008709
Task: 42043

Change-Id: I78c503a65c0c3fdb17773279d87db425926fa275

commit_message:
Base unit test framework to test new API policy enforcement

It is just base framework which will help adding tests for various
API policy rules.

Partially-Implements blueprint: secure-rbac-roles

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-19 15:11:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix invalid JSON generated by quota details

The value fetched by Quotasv2_detail.get_resources() is ultimately
returned by Reservation.get_total_reservations_map. The total_reserved
value is returned by a sqlalchemy sum(), and is of a type defined by
the database driver in use. PyMySQL returns a Decimal here, which
the api layer serialises to JSON as a string.

Note that if a resource has no reservations then its value will be
defaulted in DbQuotaDriver.get_detailed_tenant_quotas to the integer
value 0. This means that the value is an integer if zero, or a string
otherwise. This causes parsing difficulties for client libraries which
do strict type checking.

Testing note:
This method is already covered by the unit test
TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource, which also already
tests the return value and, implicitly, its type. However, it does not
currently fail because the unit tests run with SQLite rather than MySQL.
SQLite returns an int where MySQL returns a Decimal, which does not
trigger the bug.

TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource is sufficient to
demonstrate that the patch doesn't regress SQLite. We were not able to
think of a deterministic way to write a Tempest test for this, which
would cover MySQL. Ideally we would have the ability to run the DB test
suites under MySQL and PostreSQL in addition to SQLite using oslo.db's
OpportunisticDbFixture, but the scope of that is larger than this
change.

Closes-Bug: #1918565
Change-Id: Icda0d63f2f5ea72bde423296c76aa46646fa98a8
(cherry picked from commit 9ed17cec2d4ce0bd27e37c2877a413f5b302f4cd)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix invalid JSON generated by quota details

The value fetched by Quotasv2_detail.get_resources() is ultimately
returned by Reservation.get_total_reservations_map. The total_reserved
value is returned by a sqlalchemy sum(), and is of a type defined by
the database driver in use. PyMySQL returns a Decimal here, which
the api layer serialises to JSON as a string.

Note that if a resource has no reservations then its value will be
defaulted in DbQuotaDriver.get_detailed_tenant_quotas to the integer
value 0. This means that the value is an integer if zero, or a string
otherwise. This causes parsing difficulties for client libraries which
do strict type checking.

Testing note:
This method is already covered by the unit test
TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource, which also already
tests the return value and, implicitly, its type. However, it does not
currently fail because the unit tests run with SQLite rather than MySQL.
SQLite returns an int where MySQL returns a Decimal, which does not
trigger the bug.

TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource is sufficient to
demonstrate that the patch doesn't regress SQLite. We were not able to
think of a deterministic way to write a Tempest test for this, which
would cover MySQL. Ideally we would have the ability to run the DB test
suites under MySQL and PostreSQL in addition to SQLite using oslo.db's
OpportunisticDbFixture, but the scope of that is larger than this
change.

Closes-Bug: #1918565
Change-Id: Icda0d63f2f5ea72bde423296c76aa46646fa98a8
(cherry picked from commit 9ed17cec2d4ce0bd27e37c2877a413f5b302f4cd)

commit_message:
test integrate with docker-compose

There are serveral reason to do this.

- operators chould re-create the container very easily. just use
  docker-compose up or down
  
- all the container parameters are saved in the disk. operators could
  know waht is the exact parameters used.
  
- This also simplified the ansible logical.

Change-Id: I1f09b6702b26175011bf53acbcbae29c510889f5

commit_message:
Implement Almanach ansible role

Almanach record the utilization of OpenStack resources for each tenant.
Add ansible role to deploy Almanach.

Implements: blueprint almanach-ansible-role
Change-Id: I214885354a2bbf4629fc534e92019f69069d711d
Depends-On: Iba2e16772864a6f0169ec43d7a87d741882cd51c

Change-Id: I1b55b1fcddb405d380189cd4474685e4e828c095

commit_message:
Fix vagrant dev env build

Remove references to genconfig and kolla-build.yml so the vagrant
environment can be built without error.

Change-Id: I1b55b1fcddb405d380189cd4474685e4e828c095

commit_message:
[WIP] Added playbooks for snap deployment

Snap is a telemetry-framework that can be used to collect
and publish metrics. This patch adds playbook for its deployment.
This patch also adds template of task manifest from which SNAP tasks are
created.

Change-Id: I32813dd353e96a02c826cfc541a1af4e8d7a91a4
Partially-implements: bp/monitoring
Co-Authored-By: Sayantani Goswami <sayantani.goswami@intel.com>

subject: Add Apache License Content in index.rst
messages:
[{'account_id': 25493, 'date': '2017-04-15 02:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-15 02:58:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-kolla-ansible-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/89/456989/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-docs-ubuntu-xenial/8c00026//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 49s'}, {'account_id': 22959, 'date': '2017-04-15 04:07:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Can you explain why add the Apache License
I think there is no need here'}, {'account_id': 25493, 'date': '2017-04-15 04:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Can you explain why add the Apache License
 > I think there is no need here

Hi,thank you for reviewing my patch^^

I checked the rule and value of adding license statement to souce code from here: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LegalIssuesFAQ#Copyright_Headers. Please have a check.

As it describes, though the copyright for souce code file is not mandatory, but it notices from code taken from outside of OpenStack will typically need to be preserved as a requirement of the license of that external code.

And I also checked this kind of patch for other OpenStack project, many projects have merged this copyright into source code release file already. So in order to keep consistent, I wang to add this copyright patch in.'}, {'account_id': 22959, 'date': '2017-04-17 06:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

hi, there is uncommon to add Apache License in releasenotes, can you point which project doing this？'}, {'account_id': 25493, 'date': '2017-04-17 08:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> hi, there is uncommon to add Apache License in releasenotes, can
 > you point which project doing this？

Hi, I found one here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/455263/

Add Apache License Content in index.rst

1. What is the problem?
Apache License 2.0 is lack in ./releasenotes/source/index.rst

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Add Apache License 2.0 Content which is necessary
for ./releasenotes/source/index.rst.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to realize the solution?
No need

commit_message:
Remove layout overrides and use tripleo-ci templates instead

As part of [1] and in line with all other tripleo repos lets use
the tripleo-ci templates. The files: and irrelevant-files matches
are moved to tripleo-ci in the depends-on. This leaves only the
undercloud-minion job in the overrides as it isn't covered by the
templates, but updates tags.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:tripleo-ci-reduce

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/781322

Change-Id: Id8bdcc314f68fb35050254c6c64fd2317c2555de

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I6a30ef8373ba30cbc9c9d0d6de1d640dc349d967

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie501d9e209309990a0ec4d7a4be6f306277cb2b4

subject: Fix condition when to create backends
messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-03-25 07:59:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 31542, 'date': '2021-03-25 10:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-03-25 10:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-25 07:59:54.000000000', 'message': 'Fix condition when to create backends

Backend creation should happen on the last host in the group, instead
of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while
other containers are not ready yet. Thus we should be creating backends
at the very end of the deployment, when all containers are set.

Change-Id: I3d5811e059d1b5cb3e87fe7657872e41105c832e
Closes-Bug: #1920964
'}]
commit_message:
Fix condition when to create backends

Backend creation should happen on the last host in the group, instead
of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while
other containers are not ready yet. Thus we should be creating backends
at the very end of the deployment, when all containers are set.

Change-Id: I3d5811e059d1b5cb3e87fe7657872e41105c832e
Closes-Bug: #1920964

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.

commit_message:
Set 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options in the 'libvirt' plugin to be defined in conf.d/libvirt.yaml

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.
However, in 'monasca_agent/collector/virt/libvirt/inspector.py' file these options cannot be
provided by a configuration file. Changing this to retrieve both options from
'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' file.

Change-Id: I1918fda471e951f42db0d302e371108b664e936c
(cherry picked from commit 085f64578f40152273138898a0dc4566d327dc8f)

[{'created': '2021-03-24 16:36:54.000000000', 'message': '[dnm]

Change-Id: I5b09dc3bc52d98df756cdc60c5e94cd1e7344e9a
'}, {'created': '2021-03-24 18:18:29.000000000', 'message': 'Retry on creating trove network

For pretty weird reason, first request to create a network to the neutron
fails with 500 without reasonable stack trace. Re-running request succeeds.
So we adding retries to the task which resolves metnioned issue.

Change-Id: I5b09dc3bc52d98df756cdc60c5e94cd1e7344e9a

commit_message:
Retry on creating trove network

For pretty weird reason, first request to create a network to the neutron
fails with 500 without reasonable stack trace. Re-running request succeeds.
So we adding retries to the task which resolves metnioned issue.

Change-Id: I5b09dc3bc52d98df756cdc60c5e94cd1e7344e9a

Fix usage of tags

Tags are working differently with includes vs imports, so we should
respect that and use appropriently.

messages: [{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-23 14:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-25 10:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-23 14:49:13.000000000', 'message': 'Use Python3 in client side to run Python2 functional tests

This change makes Python2 functional tests use Python 3 client side
to avoid "InterpreterNotFound: python2.7" error with tox in focal.
Server side processes are still launched on Python 2.7.

Change-Id: Ie2ac2b6c05d54e5a7798447ce7c120c2422140e4
'}]
commit_message:
Use Python3 in client side to run Python2 functional tests

This change makes Python2 functional tests use Python 3 client side
to avoid "InterpreterNotFound: python2.7" error with tox in focal.
Server side processes are still launched on Python 2.7.

Change-Id: Ie2ac2b6c05d54e5a7798447ce7c120c2422140e4

subject: Add warning log when restarting docker container
messages: [{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-01-30 06:46:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-03-25 10:44:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nThis change doesn't affect behavior but makes some changes in logging for better visibility. So I'd approve this by myself now."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-30 06:46:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add warning log when restarting docker container

When a storlet application or its dependencies are updated, we first
try restarting storlet daemon, but if it fails then we restart the
whole container, which might cause ungraceful shutdown of the other
storlet daemon in the same container.

This change adds a warning log so that operators can understand how
many times such stop failure have happened in the deployment.

Change-Id: I2843bf1118505a2e32e1f80e7329ed73de1cd62d
'}]
commit_message:
Add warning log when restarting docker container

When a storlet application or its dependencies are updated, we first
try restarting storlet daemon, but if it fails then we restart the
whole container, which might cause ungraceful shutdown of the other
storlet daemon in the same container.

This change adds a warning log so that operators can understand how
many times such stop failure have happened in the deployment.

Change-Id: I2843bf1118505a2e32e1f80e7329ed73de1cd62d

commit_message:
backup dependents failure

Incremental backup created fails, its parent_id will record the id of the parent backup, but num_dependent_backup is not increased by 1, resulting in has_dependent_backups being false, but the deletion of the parent backup will fails. This patch adds 1 to the num_dependent_backup of the parent backup when the backup creation fails.

Change-Id: I97afdc561b346abb87c3801aaab4b9f3e7492d6d
Closes-Bug: #1907542

commit_message:
Nova kubernetes changes

* Changed interface to listen to 0.0.0.0
* Allows the user to point at a cluster for the following services that
  isn't defined by the Ansible hostvars:
	* RabbitMQ
	* MemcacheD
	* Neutron
	* Keystone

Change-Id: Iadbdd3aa43f9ba91ec820220fb8828e69161c579
Co-authored-by: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>
Partially-implements: blueprint api-interface-bind-address-override

(2 comments)

As long as this buffering layer isn't a requirement, im sure some people would find it useful.

I will say, 90% of this can be achieved with haproxy right now. Haproxy has the ability to drain connections from hosts and remove hosts from pools via a socket. Doing that would allow rolling upgrades with no downtime for most services. This would be better in general since restarting a service can kill active connections (even with this purposed spec).

I think the buffering would only be useful in hard cluster stops of mariadb or rabbitmq. However, that should only occur during major upgrades of one openstack release to another. Since some services also require a hard stop (like nova). I am not sure if that alone would make for a good reason to have an always-running buffering service like this."}, {'account_id': 22582, 'date': '2016-12-12 10:13:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I replied inline. Let me know if I haven't addressed all of your points."}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2016-12-12 11:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For the record, Kolla has not implemented proper neutron upgrades yet, the way we do upgrades has downtime. That is where the effort should be focused.

I believe you have a patch up to work on this Duong.

Again though, with connection draining and proper upgrades you can actually achieve 100% uptime without connection buffering like this. Connection buffering would simply be hiding the problem of not doing upgrades properly.'}, {'account_id': 22582, 'date': '2016-12-14 02:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

 > should be focused.
 > 
 > I believe you have a patch up to work on this Duong.
 > 
 > Again though, with connection draining and proper upgrades you can
 > actually achieve 100% uptime without connection buffering like
 > this. Connection buffering would simply be hiding the problem of
 > not doing upgrades properly.

Hi Sam,

The demo video is based on my ps [1] which implements Neutron rolling upgrade and you can see there is still downtime here.

In general, many OpenStack services have not implemented rolling upgrade yet, which means for these services, we need take down whole service for awhile. HAproxy draining connections cannot be used to solve this problem.

Thanks,

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/407922/'}, {'account_id': 7488, 'date': '2016-12-14 08:18:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

 > you saw. Connection buffering just hides the issue you saw.

Can you give me some hints?

About connection buffering: with this trick, from user's PoV, there is no downtime at all, just laggy (if db upgrade time is too lag, user still see downtime when connection is timeout)'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2016-12-14 21:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ok. I would like to clear up some info.

First, to handle "zero-downtime upgrades" we absolutely must drain connections to the loadbalancer properly. That is a must. Without that we will have broken connections.

Second, to do neutron upgrades we must expand the database (online) and then contract the database (offline). The offline migration takes a very short amount of time, but that would be hard downtime which this patch is trying to avoid.

I have a hard time swallowing the idea of a buffering piece that is _always_ im place just to make upgrades a bit easier. That seems like a bad idea. However, I think we may be able to do some haproxy cleverness where we can add in this buffering piece as a new host when we upgrade and disable the other hosts. This would allow the buffering host to hold all the connections temporarily. Once the upgrades are done, we can dump the buffered connections back into the haproxy pool and remove the buffering piece.

That would achieve the no lost api messages without introducing a buffering piece that is always running. The only downside to what i describe would be the potential for out-of-order messages. Though, that shouldn't cause problems due to the nature of RESTapis.

Anyway, there is the additional info I have looked up.'}, {'account_id': 19741, 'date': '2016-12-15 03:28:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Ok. I would like to clear up some info.
 > 
 > First, to handle "zero-downtime upgrades" we absolutely must drain
 > connections to the loadbalancer properly. That is a must. Without
 > that we will have broken connections.
 > 

+1

 > Second, to do neutron upgrades we must expand the database (online)
 > and then contract the database (offline). The offline migration
 > takes a very short amount of time, but that would be hard downtime
 > which this patch is trying to avoid.
 > 

The contract phase could take a very large amount of time in case of big DB as inc0 mention is last IRC meeting. That's why we think next step would be canary or blue-green upgrade implemented in Kolla.

 > I have a hard time swallowing the idea of a buffering piece that is
 > _always_ im place just to make upgrades a bit easier. That seems
 > like a bad idea. However, I think we may be able to do some haproxy
 > cleverness where we can add in this buffering piece as a new host
 > when we upgrade and disable the other hosts. This would allow the
 > buffering host to hold all the connections temporarily. Once the
 > upgrades are done, we can dump the buffered connections back into
 > the haproxy pool and remove the buffering piece.
 > 

Great idea, we will add this to the spec. Thank you Sam!

 > That would achieve the no lost api messages without introducing a
 > buffering piece that is always running. The only downside to what i
 > describe would be the potential for out-of-order messages. Though,
 > that shouldn't cause problems due to the nature of RESTapis.
 > 

We have done some benchmark and testing with OpenResty. It could hold up to 1 million simple requests in 30 minutes and ensure the message ordering (somehow you can see in demo clip while we send the create/delete network requests in order). But, we need to re-test with complex requests. Will send the report later.

 > Anyway, there is the additional info I have looked up.

We too, thank you for invaluable comments :-)'}, {'account_id': 22582, 'date': '2016-12-28 01:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22582, 'date': '2016-12-28 01:37:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

I added this to the spec.

@Jeffrey Zhang: Thanks for the review.

1. I'm working on figuring out what broke.

2. For our production system, I want to ensure that we can upgrade horizon from one major version to another without downtime and without breaking existing browser sessions. (For example, upgrading Mitaka to Newton). The corresponding Kolla-Kubernetes patches enables you to have a pool of Mitaka and a pool of Newton Horizons running in parallel, and this load balancer directs traffic to the correct cluster so users don't see any breakage.

2.1 If I were deploying with ansible instead of k8s, I'd want the same functionality, but I don't know enough about ansible to implement it myself, and it would be much tougher to implement I think with ansible since ansible doesn't have k8s's load balancing/container networking.

2.2 kolla-kubernetes relies on kolla for all of its config generation. So that's why its here and not there."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-22 09:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

[{'created': '2016-06-24 23:29:51.000000000', 'message': 'Horizon Frontend - (for kolla-kubernetes)

Horizon is a web application that is distributed between the web
server, and the web browser. If the web server is upgraded while
the application is still running on the web browser, unusual issues
can creep up.

This patch allows for an haproxy based frontend container to be
created that, through kolla config options, allows multiple horizon
backends to be defined, browsers to be temporarily bound to the
versions they initially landed on, and new horizons introduced for
testing and promotion to default.

Two new variables are defined:
 * horizon_versions: an array of versions that are part of the
   system. Defaults to ["1"]
 * horizon_version_default: new browser sessions coming in are
   defaulted to this version. Defaults to "1"

So, for example, with the following config, older existing sessions
will continue to work on version 1 (say, Mitaka based), and all new
connections will go to version 2 (say, Newton based), allowing
version 1 to be gracefully drained and eventually deleted:
  horizon_versions: ["1", "2"]
  horizon_version_default: "2"

It is intended to be used along with corresponding logic in Kolla-Kubernetes.

Change-Id: I2dcd0fc224a959cc36cb7fd2a2adc99be280b7ff

commit_message:
Horizon Frontend - (for kolla-kubernetes)

Horizon is a web application that is distributed between the web
server, and the web browser. If the web server is upgraded while
the application is still running on the web browser, unusual issues
can creep up.

This patch allows for an haproxy based frontend container to be
created that, through kolla config options, allows multiple horizon
backends to be defined, browsers to be temporarily bound to the
versions they initially landed on, and new horizons introduced for
testing and promotion to default.

Two new variables are defined:
 * horizon_versions: an array of versions that are part of the
   system. Defaults to ["1"]
 * horizon_version_default: new browser sessions coming in are
   defaulted to this version. Defaults to "1"

So, for example, with the following config, older existing sessions
will continue to work on version 1 (say, Mitaka based), and all new
connections will go to version 2 (say, Newton based), allowing
version 1 to be gracefully drained and eventually deleted:
  horizon_versions: ["1", "2"]
  horizon_version_default: "2"

It is intended to be used along with corresponding logic in Kolla-Kubernetes.

Change-Id: I2dcd0fc224a959cc36cb7fd2a2adc99be280b7ff

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE!: PoC of ansible override

We can't merge this until we deal with license issues. This strategy
plugin will allow to include custom tasks into ansible playbook without
changing kolla code.

To include file after any task with Aodh in name, put this into
globals.yml

ansible_override:
    include_after:
        task: "Aodh"
        file: "/home/ubuntu/test.yml"

Change-Id: If5f6a6479ebf5b94a2a55dc40d55c2e00f20a5e4

commit_message:
Update docs of Instantiate CNF for scale and heal

Usage guides for how to deploy ETSI NFV-SOL containerized VNF is added
in user docs.
This patch updates the VNFD for CNF scale and heal operation, and
updates result of show command.

- kolla-coverage-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/31/427931/1/check/kolla-coverage-ubuntu-xenial/3af314d/ : SUCCESS in 1m 06s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 10787, 'date': '2017-02-01 23:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, building in dockerhub would require us to ditch jinja2 which would remove our ability to reuse same image across the board, modify it or edit base image if someone wants to for example use rdo based one:)'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2017-02-02 16:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Well, building in dockerhub would require us to ditch jinja2 which
 > would remove our ability to reuse same image across the board,
 > modify it or edit base image if someone wants to for example use
 > rdo based one:)

What about if we generated the various docker files with jinja2 as normal, but generate all of them flattened out and check them into a different repo on merge with a zuul hook. then point docker hub at that repo? Docker hub could then build them all itself.'}, {'account_id': 14119, 'date': '2017-02-02 16:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

frankly i feel like doing this is the wrong approach.

using mariadb:10.1 directly and binding in your configs at runtime (with kolla-ansible or whatever tool you are using) is the better option in my opinion.'}, {'account_id': 10787, 'date': '2017-02-02 18:17:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, that might be next step, approach here allows us to change image arch with little effect on ansible code - easier to implement without rewritting bunch of stuff'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2017-02-02 23:22:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

who knows how this image was built.  It could be built for centos, or it could be built for ubuntu.  The problem here is the system call interface, ioctl interface, RTNETLINK interface, and many other kernel interfaces are incompatible between different kernel.orgs and different glibcs.  This is a real problem, not theoretical - hence why we have distro implementations for various distros.

When you consider the emerging ARM work as well, this seems like a non-starter to me.  I am pretty close to a -2 on this approach, however, I'd like to hear more from other core reviewers."}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2017-02-02 23:44:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not a kolla core, so not sure how much vote I get, but I think as an additional way to build containers, it seems viable. As an exclusive way, I'm much less convinced. Some operators trust there favourite distro way more as an upstream then the source of the original source of the software, or a hub container that may or may not have been provided by the original source of the software.

I think we should talk about this more at the PTG though."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 04:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-03-25 11:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Do not use mirror host for Ceph Luminous

Luminous is still used for Debian jobs, but mirror host doesn't provide
the required contents.

Change-Id: I1120e881b0e7844978024ccab03b1f2eab97b098
(cherry picked from commit 8c58e4e304c43ecb66769d3fc34c92c3fd9127ea)

(cherry picked from commit c6057afe6ad62508b3fb059c29a612184f1bbbeb)

commit_message:
[WIP] Added snap-telemetry container

Add container with snap-telemetry framework, that can be used
for collecting and processing metrics.

Change-Id: Idc18d6eaef28efb2702bc8cda3da83340d2db8b5
Partially-Implements: blueprint monitoring

commit_message:
Install the plugin of elasticsearch-kopf

Kopf is an ElasticSearch management tool
that  provides APIs for ES cluster operations.

Change-Id: I99371bdca40626c9611dfec31083dc3eb8465c38

commit_message:
Install the plugin of elasticsearch-head

Install the plugin of elasticsearch-head which is a management tool,
through it to see elasticsearch running status and data.

Change-Id: I3d9b02aae5f35631ee294781f6c7ad702adfa657

commit_message:
Fix vagrant dev env

Remove references to kolla-ansible related files which were previously
removed from the repository so vagrant can build without errors.

Change-Id: I673c2ea977cef35981d5d5e9c6dff628aa44fda4

(5 comments)

Now I think I understand why You want to have this config option. Bug reported by Nate was happening more likely after few reboots of vm, one reboot may not be enough to reproduce that issue. And that's why You want to run that test in Your d/s CI jobs with more reboot attempts than just one.
But in u/s ci, where we don't have nested virtualization, such test may be very long and I think that it will be better to run it with one reboot. So setting default value of those reboots to 1 would be better IMO."}, {'account_id': 20171, 'date': '2021-01-20 15:47:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
New test, extends test_subport_connectivity

Related-Bug: #1869244

Adding new test, test_subport_connectivity_soft_reboot
The test is checking trunks and ports are recreated during server
reboots, especialy in ovs_dpdk ports,
Since test flow is variant of test_subport_connectivity
Two methods added and used in the tests:
_create_servers_with_trunk_port
_check_servers_remote_connectivity

Change-Id: Ia5fbe680bb904680f52e0e15056d629717a643af

commit_message:
[WIP] POC of buffering layer for Neutron

Intermission can be used as buffer layer for OpenStack service.

Demonstrated in [1]

[1] https://www.openstack.org/videos/boston-2017/openstack-cluster-zero-downtime-upgrade-with-kolla

The default port of Docker registry is 5000. But the 5000 port is also
the port of keystone-api. To avoid conflict, use 4000 port as Docker
registry port.

Change-Id: I3885cdbb3d4e68db2d34e479b2e974286036fdd7
'}, {'created': '2016-12-29 12:01:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Docker registry port error in image-building.rst

commit_message:
Fix Docker registry port error in image-building.rst

The default port of Docker registry is 5000. But the 5000 port is also
the port of keystone-api. To avoid conflict, use 4000 port as Docker
registry port.

Change-Id: I3885cdbb3d4e68db2d34e479b2e974286036fdd7

commit_message:
Add UEFI deploy file in ironic pxe container

Currently, ironic which deployed by kolla-ansible just support pxe
method to deploy OS, add support for UEFI deploy.

The UEFI support guide is in "PXE UEFI setup" section:
https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html

Change-Id: I52c4c3a2088b024d2173260910efc93a4ec4b06c

commit_message:
Use 'project' instead of 'tenant'

While switching to openstackclient we use project instead
of tenant.

Change-Id: I93202c371a263f2ed8dace0dc8d3db5c9c8cf16c

subject: Kube OVS DB to listen on tcp:port and neutron-ovs-agent to use script
messages:
[{'account_id': 19384, 'date': '2016-08-18 22:59:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10787, 'date': '2016-08-18 23:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-08-18 23:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I really don't like this approach.

* It adds kubernetes specific stuff to the container abi, which I believe is unnecessary. At minimal, it needs to only add runtime specified tunnel_interface to override.
* It uses hostname -i which won't work for our cloud, ignoring tunnel_interface
* uses sed to deal with ini parsing, which can be fragile

See alternate approach here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/356114"}, {'account_id': 19384, 'date': '2016-08-18 23:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Kevin, I am ok to use approach you suggested with tunnel_interface and get ip address from it. hostname -i I used just to get going.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-08-18 23:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

why make ovsdb public? seems like a security risk.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-08-18 23:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

the k8s specific code could be stripped out by just doing this always:
if [ -z ${TUNNEL_INTERFACE+x} ]; then
  #make changes to ini file
fi

the abi then is enhanced to allow the user to specify TUNNEL_INTERFACE in a docker env var.

Still currently thinking this patch is unneeded though.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-08-19 00:14:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

commit_message:
Kube OVS DB to listen on tcp:port and neutron-ovs-agent to use script

This PS adds tcp socket to ovsdb process to listen to and it also changes
neutron-openvswitch-agent start command. It will start via script which  now
accepts orchestration specific parameters.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I0c5e51fbce7776ba38eb1cca4b040017b0d69351

commit_message:
Add external ceph support for cinder and glance

Modify the conditional strategy for cinder and glance regarding ceph:
use cinder_volume_driver and glance_volume_driver instead of
enable_ceph.

Introduced some config values into globals.yml and passwords.yml to be
able to use the ceph driver without deploying a ceph cluster.

This strategy could be used in other versions.

WARNING: before merging into "stable", please test the non-regression
in the "enable_ceph=yes" situation (deploying a ceph cluster). It
should be compatible but has not been tested.

Co-Authored-By: Mathias Ewald <mewald@evoila.de>
Change-Id: If05eefcf1c91e4d564ec32d12d144f47564162d6
Implements: spec external-ceph
Signed-off-by: Sebastien Fuchs <sebastien@emmene-moi.fr>

commit_message:
Optimize bluestore deployment in kolla

The following optimizations were made to the bluestore deployment:

1. Change osd partition-related naming rules to easily obtain relevant
disk information
2. In find_disks.py, separate the disk information of ceph and other
components, and optimize disk results for filestore and bluestore,
discard disk information that is not relevant.
3. Direct use of disk partition variables, no additional judgment is
required to determine the disk type.
4. Supports three combinations of partition labels to initialize osd.
5. Solved the problem of block partition computing weight error.
6. Modify the type id of the osd partition to avoid container startup
failure caused by ceph automount.

Change-Id: Ic2cd282eb81368b7361a8012544e0b240102e3f5
Closes-bug: #1776888

subject: WIP - kuryr-ocp job
messages:
[{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2021-03-25 02:26:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2021-03-25 02:27:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2021-03-25 02:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2021-03-25 03:13:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2021-03-25 03:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2021-03-25 10:54:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Most OpenShift container images are built with golang meaning that they don't suffer much from e.g. dependency hell. As a Python project kuryr-kubernetes doesn't have some advantages and basically the upstream OpenStack builds are different than the ones built for OpenShift. In particular:

1. We have some special OpenShift-related patches in github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes. I already thought that we should upstream them so that's something we'll need in order to enable this approach.
2. There's issue with dependencies - i.e. OpenShift Kuryr is built using RDO RPMs meaning that Python deps are a bit dated. On the other hand the OpenStack Kuryr uses pypi and mostly gets latest packages. This is mostly seen with openstacksdk where to support RDO's version of packages we have several hacks in place to add functionalities from newer versions. I don't really see a nice way to solve this, I think I'd rather test regular upstream builds here."}]

commit_message:
WIP - kuryr-ocp job

Do not review yet, it's a starting point to have a single-node job
 that will build kuryr image, push it to a registry and deploy an OCP
 cluster against an OpenStack public cloud using that Kuryr image and
 see the results.

Change-Id: I86735beb07384fceeb02006c35e48c225a4b160e
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-05 08:09:57.000000000', 'message': "Deploy bluestore directly with partition name in kolla

1.In the bluestore initialization code, the device name and the
partition sequence are used to splicing the partition name, but
this causes a certain code redundancy and doesn't support other
devices, such as bcache devices. This patch solves this problem
and uses the partition name directly.
2.Optimized the return information of find_disks.py, only returns
valid disk information, does not return null values.
3.When osd_initial_weight is auto, kolla will calculate the weight
according to the size of the disk, so when using bluestore, it need
to calculate the weight according to the size of the block.

Change-Id: I5b544a966edf5f0814cc14fd964d04c4687045e1
"}, {'created': '2018-09-05 08:32:19.000000000', 'message': "Use partition name directly for bluestore in kolla
